title: Paul's Gospel and Human Sinfulness
shortSummary: Romans Chapter 1 introduces Paul as the apostle called to preach the gospel of Jesus Christ. The chapter highlights the power of the gospel for salvation and reveals humanity’s rejection of God, resulting in divine judgment and moral decay. It sets the foundation for understanding both God’s righteousness and human unrighteousness.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul writes the Epistle to the Romans during his third missionary journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of Romans, called to preach the gospel and establish believers in faith.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God, whose resurrection declares His divine power and through whom salvation is offered.

keyCharacters.name: Believers in Rome
keyCharacters.description: Recipients of Paul’s letter, described as called saints and recipients of grace and peace.

definitions.definition: One who is sent with a special commission to preach the gospel and establish the church.
The good news of salvation through Jesus Christ, His death, and resurrection.
God’s righteous judgment and anger against sin and unrighteousness.
A mind abandoned by God to sinful thoughts and actions due to persistent rejection of Him.
God’s perfect justice and moral purity, revealed through faith in Jesus Christ.

outline.heading: Paul’s Introduction and Apostolic Calling
outline.description: Paul introduces himself as a servant and apostle called to preach the gospel of God concerning Jesus Christ, emphasizing His divine Sonship and the promise fulfilled through the prophets.

outline.heading: Paul’s Desire to Visit the Roman Believers
outline.description: Paul expresses gratitude for the faith of the Roman believers, his continual prayers for them, and his longing to impart spiritual gifts to strengthen their faith.

outline.heading: The Power and Righteousness of the Gospel
outline.description: Paul boldly declares he is not ashamed of the gospel, which is the power of God for salvation to all who believe, revealing God’s righteousness by faith.

outline.heading: God’s Wrath Revealed Against Human Sin
outline.description: Paul explains how humanity suppresses the truth about God, resulting in idolatry, moral corruption, and God giving them over to sinful desires and a reprobate mind, deserving of death.

application: Trust in the gospel as the power of God for salvation and live by faith daily.
Recognize the seriousness of rejecting God’s truth and avoid idolatry in all forms.
Pray earnestly for fellow believers to grow in faith and spiritual gifts.
Examine your heart for any areas where you may be suppressing God’s truth and repent.

keyVerses.text: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
keyVerses.significance: This verse declares the gospel’s power to save all who believe and sets the tone for the entire epistle.

keyVerses.text: For therein is the righteousness of God revealed from faith to faith: as it is written, The just shall live by faith.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals that righteousness from God is received by faith, a foundational truth for Christian doctrine.

keyVerses.text: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who hold the truth in unrighteousness;
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the theme of divine judgment against sin, emphasizing God’s holiness and justice.

keyVerses.text: Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the willful persistence in sin despite knowing God’s judgment, underscoring human depravity.
